full_text:
Case 1:20-cr-00330-PAE Document 499-2 Filed 11/23/21 Page 154 of 159
LBAAMAX5ps Rocchio - Cross
1 THE COURT: And I would suggest that the microphone point directly at you.
2 MR. PAGLIUCA: Yes.
3 THE COURT: Go ahead.
4 A. So the significance of delayed disclosure as it relates to
5 my opinion is, it is part of our understanding of phenomenology
6 of child sexual abuse and the ways in which individuals tell.
7 So I'm not identifying delayed disclosure as a predictor. I'm
8 simply saying that it is a common phenomenon that is observed
9 in the scientific literature to occur among children who are
10 sexually abused.
11 Q. Well, there are many other reasons why these reports may
12 surface not immediately. Correct?
13 A. Again, I'm commenting at this point my opinion is that
14 delayed disclosure is common. I'm not -- do you have a
15 question about the reasons why?
16 Q. Yeah. There are many reasons why. There are allegations
17 that are made months, weeks, years, after an alleged event.
18 Correct?
19 A. Correct.
20 Q. And they may or may not have anything to do with the
21 veracity of the allegation. Correct?
22 A. The reasons may not have -- again, are you -- I mean, are
23 you asking me, can people make false claims?
24 Q. Yes.
25 SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C. (212) 805-0300
DOJ-OGR-00008022

24 Q. Yes.
